text: the kremlin has said it's greatly
concerned by washington's decision to
put thousands of u.s troops on alert
because of fears of russian aggression
against ukraine accusing the united
states of whipping up tensions it comes
after u.s president joe biden the
british prime minister boris johnson and
other nato leaders met via video link to
talk about how to stop russia invading
ukraine
tension in the region has been building
with around a hundred thousand russian
troops gathered near ukraine's borders
president putin has publicly stated his
belief that russia and ukraine
are one people he claims
one of his key concerns is the expansion
of nato
that's the military alliance of european
and north american countries many
nations in eastern europe became members
after the breakup of the soviet union
the russian president's demand that
ukraine will never be allowed to join
nato has been rejected our world affairs
correspondent caroline hawley reports
the might of the russian army on display
in its ally belarus ukraine's northern
neighbour
joint military exercises are planned
next month as moscow also builds up
troops on ukraine's eastern border
some 100 000 soldiers in all amid
growing fears of a russian invasion of
another war in europe
last night western leaders held virtual
crisis talks mr speaker together with
our allies we are standing up to russian
aggression and the foreign secretary has
just announced that she'll visit ukraine
next week
a further military incursion by russia
into ukraine would be a massive
strategic mistake and come with a severe
cost on russia's economy including
coordinated sanctions
the west is trying desperately to deter
a russian attack this is a danish
frigate on its way to the baltic sea
joe biden insists western leaders are
unanimous about how to respond
he's placed eight and a half thousand
american troops on alert to deploy at
short notice to europe if they need to
the west is also threatening an
unprecedented range of sanctions if
president putin does indeed give orders
to invade we must underestimate how
serious he is a sovereign and
independent ukraine is a direct affront
to his ambitions as he sees them to
restore russia as a great power given
the maximal nature of his demands given
that he's rejected the only reasonable
compromise it's hard for me to see how
he can avoid having to follow through to
some extent
in the ukrainian capital kiev there's a
wary uncertain calm some now quietly
calculating what they'll do how they'll
keep their family safe if russia does
invade
moscow insists it has no such plans and
has accused the americans of whipping up
tensions by putting its troops on alert
but it's also made clear that diplomacy
is not yet dead leaving a glimmer of
hope that a new conflict could still be
averted caroline hawley bbc news
